Welcome to Pushkar, a small village in the northwest of India in the Thar desert of Rajasthan
every November
80,000 camel herders descend on the village to buy and sell
over 400,000 camel, cattle, and horses, before bathing themselves in the holy lake of Pushkar on the full moon
The camel is central to the culture of Rajasthan, India's largest yet least populated state where
for thousands of years these guys have used the ships of the desert
as transportation, food, and a source of leather
Rajasthan's nomadic camel herders are a tribe known as the Reika
Originally the caretakers of the Maharaja stables
they have traveled these deserts for centuries, looking for grazing ground and water for their camel herds
But this fascinating culture is struggling to survive into the modern era.
Traditional grazing grounds are shrinking
And they're being forced to off the female camels which are essential to maintaining herd size
That's why festivals like Pushkar are so important it allows the Reika to gather into one place
Express their culture and pass on traditions to the next generation
Rajasthani camel herders have great style including excellent mustaches
so much that they hold an annual longest mustache competition
